docs.snippet: Foreign Minister Soledad Alvear said the ambassadors to Cuba and Switzerland had been summoned home for consultations about left-wing guerrillas who escaped from a Santiago prison in 1996 and later surfaced in those countries. Switzerland acknowle...
docs.lead_paragraph: Foreign Minister Soledad Alvear said the ambassadors to Cuba and Switzerland had been summoned home for consultations about left-wing guerrillas who escaped from a Santiago prison in 1996 and later surfaced in those countries. Switzerland acknowledges granting asylum to one of the guerrillas but Fidel Castro has denied offering refuge to any of the escapees and his government has criticized Chile's insistence on pressing for more information about the matter. Larry Rohter (NYT)
docs.abstract: Chilean Foreign Min Soledad Alvear recalls ambassadors to Cuba and Switzerland for consultations about left-wing guerillas who escaped from Santiago prison in 1996 and later surfaced in those countries (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Two Envoys Recalled

docs.snippet: To speak to many Kashmiris today is to be told of Mohandas K. Gandhi's visit here in 1947. As Hindus and Muslims slaughtered each other during the partition of the subcontinent into India and Pakistan, Kashmiris spared each other the same fate. Ga...
docs.lead_paragraph: To speak to many Kashmiris today is to be told of Mohandas K. Gandhi's visit here in 1947. As Hindus and Muslims slaughtered each other during the partition of the subcontinent into India and Pakistan, Kashmiris spared each other the same fate. Gandhi described the Kashmir valley as a ray of hope in the darkness. To speak to many Kashmiris today is also to be told of the unspeakable curse that has since fallen on them.
docs.abstract: Rival claims over Kashmir go to heart of identities of Pakistan, which controls about third of region, and India, which controls rest; Pakistan holds it was created to offer homeland to subcontinent's Muslims, including Kashmir's Muslim majority; India sees Muslim state as necessary to its mantle as secular, multiethnic democracy; accuses Pakistan of waging proxy war in Kashmir by arming and training militants; map; chronology of key points in Kashmir's history; photo (M)

headline.main: Struggle for Kashmir Is Fueled By Clashing National Narratives

docs.snippet: For more than two decades, the 18th-century Van Horne House sat empty and forlorn on its hilltop perch overlooking East Main Street in Bridgewater, N.J., on the border of Bound Brook. But after a $500,000 interior renovation, it will open next Sat...
docs.lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, the 18th-century Van Horne House sat empty and forlorn on its hilltop perch overlooking East Main Street in Bridgewater, N.J., on the border of Bound Brook. But after a $500,000 interior renovation, it will open next Saturday in time for the 225th anniversary of the Battle of Bound Brook, when the British captured the house, which was a headquarters for Continental generals in the Revolutionary War. The Colonial Revival structure, built in the 1750's and on the state and national registers of historic places, also was known as Convivial Hall because its first owner, Philip Van Horne, entertained Loyalists and Patriots in its 14 rooms. It was then used mainly as a residence through 1934 when, timeworn and derelict, it was bought by the former American Cyanamid Corporation, which rehabilitated and used it as offices for a half century.

headline.main: POSTINGS: Renovation of 1750's Van Horne House; Reopening Set For Site Used In Revolution

docs.snippet: Israeli tanks and armored vehicles rolled into Hebron this evening, occupying the one remaining major West Bank city, while Palestinians and Israelis reported heavy fighting in other parts of the West Bank, including Jenin, where Israeli soldiers ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Israeli tanks and armored vehicles rolled into Hebron this evening, occupying the one remaining major West Bank city, while Palestinians and Israelis reported heavy fighting in other parts of the West Bank, including Jenin, where Israeli soldiers were searching house to house for weapons and wanted men. Four Palestinians and two Israelis were killed in the day's fighting.
docs.abstract: Israeli tanks and armored vehicles roll into Hebron, occupying one remaining major West Bank city, while Palestinians and Israelis report heavy fighting on other parts of West Bank; in Jenin, Israeli soldiers search house to house for weapons and wanted men; guerrilla fighters in Lebanon fire nine rockets across border into Israel, eighth crossborder attack since Mar 12; Prime Min Ariel Sharon, speaking before Pres Bush's address, says military operation in West Bank may last several weeks; in Ramallah, Yasir Arafat remains holed up in office compound for seventh day, surrounded by Israeli soldiers; in Bethlehem, as many as 150 gunmen remain barricaded for second day inside Church of the Nativity; Israeli officials claim gunmen are holding 15 or 20 priests hostage; priest inside church, in telephone interview, denies Israeli claim, saying men are not threatening priests; photos; maps; diagram (L)

headline.main: Israel Continues Sweep of Cities, Taking Hebron

docs.snippet: A Russian military helicopter carrying two generals, three senior officers and their security detail exploded in midair today and crashed in Chechnya, the second time in four months that Moscow has suffered a major loss of top commanders in the re...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Russian military helicopter carrying two generals, three senior officers and their security detail exploded in midair today and crashed in Chechnya, the second time in four months that Moscow has suffered a major loss of top commanders in the rebellious territory. As many as 14 passengers and crew members were killed, Russian military officials said tonight. Among the dead were the deputy interior minister, Gen. Mikhail Rudchenko, who oversaw Interior Ministry forces in Russia's southern administrative region that includes Chechnya, and his deputy, Gen. Nikolai Goridov.
docs.abstract: Russian military helicopter carrying two generals, three senior officers and security detail explodes in midair and crashes in Chechnya, second time in four months that Russia has suffered major loss of top commanders in rebellious territory; all 14 aboard are killed, including Deputy Interior Minister Gen Mikhail Rudchenko and deputy Gen Nikolai Goridov; Chechen rebel command claims helicopter was shot down with surface-to-air missile (M)

headline.main: Russian Officers Are Killed in Helicopter Crash in Chechnya

docs.snippet: Nearly two years after major hostilities ended here in Chechnya, the devastated republic in the Caucasus, Russian troops are killing civilians in a campaign of executions and looting that takes place alongside military operations aimed at destroyi...
docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly two years after major hostilities ended here in Chechnya, the devastated republic in the Caucasus, Russian troops are killing civilians in a campaign of executions and looting that takes place alongside military operations aimed at destroying rebel forces, according to Chechen police officials. Chechen police authorities working under the republic's pro-Russian government said in interviews over the past week that Russian Interior Ministry units, known by their acronym, Obron, have been scouting neighborhoods during mine-sweeping operations for residents who appear to have money or property worth stealing.
docs.abstract: Chechen police officials say that nearly two years after major hostilities ended in Chechnya, devastated republic in the Caucasus, Russian troops are killing civilians in campaign of executions and looting that takes place alongside military operations aimed at destroying rebel forces; say that Russian Interior Ministry units, known by their acronym, Obron, scout neighborhoods during mine-sweeping operations for residents who appear to have money or property worth stealing; Chechen police investigators say that at night, soldiers return in armored personnel carriers, some with identifying markings, and burst into houses, stealing household goods and killing witnesses; photos; maps (L)

headline.main: Police in Chechnya Accuse Russia's Troops of Murder

docs.snippet: Ethnic Tamil rebels have demanded that a ban on their group, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, be lifted before they will enter peace talks with the government to end an 18-year civil war that has killed more than 62,000 people. The government...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ethnic Tamil rebels have demanded that a ban on their group, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, be lifted before they will enter peace talks with the government to end an 18-year civil war that has killed more than 62,000 people. The government has not made clear its position on lifting the ban; the group has been designated a terrorist outfit by Sri Lanka, India, the United States and Canada. G. L. Peiris, a government official, said the issue would be discussed. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
docs.abstract: Ethnic Tamil rebels demand that ban on their group, Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, be lifted before they will enter peace talks with government of Sri Lanka to end 18-year civil war that has killed more than 62,000 people; group has been designated terrorist outfit not only by Sri Lanka but also by India, United States and Canada (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Rebels Set Condition For Talks

docs.snippet: To the Editor: I read with great interest the article on the Cabinet War Rooms in London. My husband and I were in London last September on a working vacation and a final trip before our baby was born. At the suggestion of a relative, we visited t...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I read with great interest the article on the Cabinet War Rooms in London. My husband and I were in London last September on a working vacation and a final trip before our baby was born. At the suggestion of a relative, we visited the War Rooms our second day in town. It was a very moving experience. Because neither of us was born then, it was difficult to imagine what life was like.
docs.abstract: Nina Essman letter on Anne Roiphe's December 16 article on British Cabinet War Rooms notes she was visiting them when she got news of September 11 attacks on America

docs.snippet: A trial is unfolding far from the spotlight in this East African town, but its outcome may one day ring out around the world. It is the trial of three journalists that focuses on the question, can freedom of speech degenerate into genocide? Or put...
docs.lead_paragraph: A trial is unfolding far from the spotlight in this East African town, but its outcome may one day ring out around the world. It is the trial of three journalists that focuses on the question, can freedom of speech degenerate into genocide? Or put differently, can journalism kill? According to prosecutors of the United Nations war crimes tribunal for Rwanda, the answer to both questions is a forceful yes.
docs.abstract: Three former Rwandan news media executives stand accused of genocide and incitement to genocide through their use of radio broadcasts and newspapers; their trial before United Nations war crimes tribunal will examine scope of role played by news media in massacre of more than 800,000 people in Rwanda in 1994; this is first time group of journalists stand accused before international tribunal on such grave charges since 1946, when Julius Streicher, Nazi publisher of anti-Semitic weekly Der Sturmer, appeared before Nuremberg judges; prosecutors in Rwanda case are drawing stark parallels between Der Sturmer's vitriolic campaigns against Jews before World War II and actions of some Rwandan media before and during 1994 slaughter of Tutsi; legal specialists believe outcome of current trial may set crucial precedent for future international cases; photos (M)

headline.main: Trial Centers on Role of Press During Rwanda Massacre

docs.snippet: A correction in this space on Saturday misattributed errors in an article on Wednesday about a new deployment of the Nepalese Army to deal with raids by Maoist guerrillas trying to overthrow the constitutional monarchy. The errors originated in ed...
docs.lead_paragraph: A correction in this space on Saturday misattributed errors in an article on Wednesday about a new deployment of the Nepalese Army to deal with raids by Maoist guerrillas trying to overthrow the constitutional monarchy. The errors originated in editing, not in the version transmitted by Reuters. As edited, the article misidentified the king who first sent the troops into action, in November. He was Gyanendra; King Birendra, his brother, was killed with most of the royal family last June by Crown Prince Dipendra, who also died of wounds in a shootout at the palace. The article misstated the crown prince's relationship to the current king. The crown prince was his nephew, not his brother.
docs.abstract: Correction of earlier correction regarding Feb 20 article on new deployment of Nepalese Army to deal with raids by Maoist guerrillas trying to overthrow constitutional monarchy
